qas.question: What made power distribution economically viable in Edison's lamp?
How many inventors came up with electric lamps before Thomas Edison?
How did Edison achieve a higher vacuum than other inventors?

answers.text: by use of the Sprengel pump

qas.question: Which historians wrote about the advantages of Edison's lamp over other early versions?
How many inventors do historians list that did not invent the incandescent lamp?

plausible_answers.text: by use of the Sprengel pump

qas.question: What made power distribution economically non-viable in Edison's lamp?

plausible_answers.text: effective incandescent material, a higher vacuum than others were able to achieve (by use of the Sprengel pump) and a high resistance

qas.question: What four factors made Edison's version economically viable?
Which three historians wrote the conclusion that Edison's version was more viable than other early versions?

context: In addressing the question of who invented the incandescent lamp, historians <a3_0><b7_0>Robert Friedel and Paul Israel<b7_0/><a3_0/> list <a1_0><b4_0>22<b4_0/><a1_0/> inventors of incandescent lamps prior to Joseph Swan and Thomas Edison. They conclude that Edison's version was able to outstrip the others because of a combination of three factors: an <b6_0>effective incandescent material, a higher vacuum than others were able to achieve (<a2_0><b5_0>by use of the Sprengel pump<b5_0/><a2_0/>) and a <a0_0>high resistance<b6_0/><a0_0/> that made power distribution from a centralized source economically viable.
